content:
Diagnosis:

Locally advanced gastric adenocarcinoma with signet ring cell features and peritoneal carcinomatosis

Staging:
T4bN3bM1, Stage IV at diagnosis January 2024
MSI stable, HER2 negative

Previous treatment:
Cycle 1-3 EOX completed March 2024
Cycle 4 discontinued due to progressive disease and deteriorating performance status

Previous medical history:
Type 2 diabetes
Hypertension
Chronic kidney disease stage 3

Current medications:
Ondansetron 8mg TDS PRN
Dexamethasone 4mg BD
Oxycodone MR 30mg BD
Oxycodone IR 5mg PRN
Metformin 1g BD
Ramipril 5mg OD

Current situation:
Progressive disease with new liver metastases
Deteriorating performance status (ECOG 3)
Increasing ascites requiring weekly paracentesis

I reviewed [redacted name] today who attended with his daughter. Unfortunately, his condition has significantly deteriorated since our last review three weeks ago. He reports worsening abdominal distension requiring increased frequency of paracentesis, now weekly. His appetite remains poor with early satiety, and he has lost a further 4kg, now weighing 62kg (down from 78kg at diagnosis). He is spending approximately 70% of the day in bed or resting due to fatigue.

The recent CT scan from 15/04/2024 shows disease progression with new liver metastases in segments 4 and 7, measuring up to 3.2cm, and increasing peritoneal disease with omental caking. There is moderate volume ascites and evidence of small bowel obstruction at multiple levels.

Given his deteriorating performance status and disease progression on first-line chemotherapy, we have had a detailed discussion about prognosis and goals of care. While second-line treatment options exist (weekly paclitaxel), the risks likely outweigh potential benefits at this stage. [redacted name] and his family understand this and wish to focus on symptom management.

I have referred urgently to the palliative care team for community support and referred to the hospice for assessment. We will continue with planned paracentesis as needed. I have increased his background opiates for pain control and prescribed additional anti-emetics. We will review him again in two weeks' time, sooner if needed, with involvement of the palliative care team.
